body:
> Do you know how large of a buffer the CMA library can allocate on the DE10Nano? And do you have an idea if it fails in a data buffer or instruction buffer, or micro-op buffer allocation?

@tmoreau89  I think the maximum buffer size that the CMA library can allocate on the DE10Nano board is 16MB for now. This is what I can get on the board.
```
root@de10-nano:~# cat /proc/meminfo | grep -i cma
CmaTotal:          16384 kB
CmaFree:           15972 kB
```
In addition, when I run end-to-end test with resnet-18, the `CmaFree` variable dropped quickly until it's trying to allocate `0x240000` bytes of contiguous memory and reported an error in memory allocation.

The debug message shows that it is a kind of `DataBuffer` that requires such amount of memory.
Thank you !

AKAIK, PYNQ has as large as 128MB for cma_alloc, see its documentation [here](https://pynq.readthedocs.io/en/v2.0/pynq_package/pynq.xlnk.html#pynq.xlnk.Xlnk.cma_alloc). 

To increase the buffer size for contiguous memory allocation, I guess we need to recompile the kernel and set `FORCE_MAX_ZONEORDER` to `16` for 128 MiB `CmaTotal`, or set `CONFIG_CMA_SIZE_MBYTES=128` directly in `.config` file.

changing to v16 didnt work for me. did anyone solved it?
thanks
@slyubomirsky Please review again and explicitly approve

No worries @jackwish 
It is my pleasure. These discussions are very useful :)

I am testing this change on a BERT model, and it runs fine on CPU. On GPU, I am seeing the following error:

`Check failed: ir::VerifyMemory(x, target->device_type): Direct host side access to device memory is detected in fused_nn_batch_matmul_add. Did you forget to bind?`

Do you have any thoughts?
@soiferj Likely some fused operations are not inlined. Can you check what sub-function after fusion raised this error during Relay compilation?

The error says it's coming from `split_dev_host_funcs` in `codegen/build_module.cc`. The line is 

`CHECK(ir::VerifyMemory(x, target->device_type))
        << "Direct host side access to device memory is detected in "
        << x->func_name() << ". Did you forget to bind?";`

We need to trace the Relay part of these functions (and see how their TOPI schedules are called)
You can use debug logging here to get more info
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/relay/backend/_backend.py#L51-L53
Thanks @liangfu; indeed if we want to increase the `cma_alloc` pool size we'd need to rebuild the kernel. It's already a limitation for some larger networks that have large parameter footprints.
Thanks!
Okay, I have the output. What exactly should I be looking for?
@vinx13 they can be of arbitrary size. we unify the excessive ones.
@vinx13 @tqchen what should it's schedule be?
@vinx13, nevermind, I made a mistake on my testing branch. I created a new branch, merged my changes with master, and can run the model now. Sorry about that.

I think the changes look good, but the func type unification rules changes probably merit more attention. @MarisaKirisame could you please give more explanation for the changes to the func type unification rules? (E.g., what problems do they solve? Should we have unit tests/regressions for those?) I'm trying to understand exactly what's going on there, since it's a pretty important piece of infrastructure
@slyubomirsky it is a change that come with let polymorphism. this replace InstantiateFuncType while leaving as much type arguments as possible.
Thanks @jwfromm, will follow up on your suggestions.

@jackwish, are you sure NHWC isn't faster than NCHW on ARM? In my experience I've consistently observed speeds up to 5X faster and haven't found any cases where NCHW is preferable. I'm definitely  in support of automatically altering to NHWC for arm_cpu workloads.

The CI failure doesn't look related to me...it is occurring in `test_forward_conv_batch_norm`. The output from the test actually looks correct too. Is this a known issue? Edit: issue has been resolved.

The above commit:
1. Fixed the failed unit test that was caused by too small shape (=1) in reduce axis.
2. Added fallback config for both cases.
Thanks for addressing the feedback. I think these changes are good (pending linting fixes)
I suppose it is probably a more principled approach than what we had before :+1:

> @jackwish, are you sure NHWC isn't faster than NCHW on ARM? In my experience I've consistently observed speeds up to 5X faster and haven't found any cases where NCHW is preferable. I'm definitely in support of automatically altering to NHWC for arm_cpu workloads.

Hi @jwfromm , sorry if I made any confusing comments, but I was saying that NHWC is *not always* faster than NCHW. To achieve better performance, sound schedule is needed.

It's really impressive to obtain 5X performance for NHWC over NCHW, which I think this PR cannot make it happen (sad story)... Would you please share more your design if that's is possible? I am sure it must be inspiring and insightful!

@cchung100m Can you take a look at the ci failure?

Since posit/bfloat/float9 are floating point number systems, they could be supported by a single floating point data path. 

Pros:
1- a single VTA instantiation would be able to support a wide range of programs and data types
2- tensor compositions could take advantage of different data types to capture the required precision/dynamic range of the operator(s)

Cons:
1- data type identifiers are needed to steer the data path to select the right operations. 
2- the data path resource efficiency could become a problem for FPGA implementations.
3- accumulators for the sum of products that underlay the dot products of the matvec/matmul operators, would have very different sizes depending on the number system. We would need to use the largest size and thus create yet additional inefficiency.

Got rid of the type check when initializing the module because I realized that would lead to lots of redundant re-type checking. The interface to the ChangeBatch pass should probably be reconsidered, though, since it seems a bit fragile (the AST gets rebuilt when type checking is rerun, so pointer equalities between vars no longer hold).

Still have not figured out how to deal with the unification bug in the cases noted before in the discussion.

Hi @kevinthesun 

Thanks for the reminder, I am working on it.

I don't have a problem with BatchMatMul change, but what is the bug it fixes? And should other `attr['_output_shapes']` uses be changed too?

I was testing out a BERT model which was exported with `(add_shapes=True)`, but then ran the GraphTransform `FoldConstants`. For whatever reason, this seemed to remove shape information from the graph. In my testing, this was the only operator that threw this issue.

I don't think we need to do this for each operator quite yet. This fix is just a more future-proof way of coding this logic.
Thanks everyone for your help and feedback :) This PR has been approved for the past few days - would someone be able to take a look at merging when they get a chance?

@yzhliu Can you please review this? This is for reading an MxNet quantized graph
@anijain2305 made the changes that we discussed.

Have not been able to fix the issue outlined in the above comment. My idea was to introduce function types as having the most general possible checked type (e.g., suppose a function's annotated type is `fun[a](?t1, ?t2) -> List[a]`. We will generalize the function's type as `fun[a, b, c](b, c) -> List[a]`, filling in the incomplete types with new variables) and then specialize it later, but I think our unification is not powerful enough to accommodate this (or I went about it badly).
Please review @MarisaKirisame @jroesch
@yidawang @comaniac Please review
Thanks @llehtahw this is merged

However I am still unable to execute `make vta`. Specifically, [the advanced configuration](https://docs.tvm.ai/vta/install.html#advanced-configuration-optional) does not work for me. I am getting the following error on a fresh tvm install (195973c0a136c739c15f238fb4db6b433bf505c6).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15805984/64853824-8fb5de80-d61c-11e9-9722-2993528979fd.png)

> Hey @diamantopoulos ,
>

Hi @vegaluisjose , thanks a lot!

> I see. I am not sure, I didn't try that out. However, we may want to think about not relaying on `_output_shape` in the future.

It works, but it is very slow. Without shape information got from TF, Frontend will have to infer type for each new added node. For a model containing about 8000 nodes, it will take more than 1.5 hours to import a graph.
